title: Ravioli, the puffin, got a sibling named Macaroni
text:
A puffin chick named Macaroni joins its siblings Gnocchi and Ravioli at the National Aquarium. (David Coffey/National Aquarium)

Macaroni, a baby puffin, has been born at the National Aquarium in Baltimore, joining its pasta-named siblings Ravioli and Gnocchi.

Officials said puffins get named at the aquarium “according to their lineage,” and using a theme in the puffin families helps the staff easily recognize “how the puffins are related.”

The puffins all have unique names. There’s another family of puffins — parents Victor and Vixen who had a puffin chick named Vega in August 2018. Puffin parents Princess and Jasper welcomed Sage in July 2018. Sage has a sibling named Willow.

Macaroni is the 16th puffin chick that has successfully hatched at the aquarium since 2006, officials said.

[Atlantic puffins pairs are plentiful this year, Audubon scientist says]

Baby Macaroni hatched on Aug. 31 after a 31-day incubation period, officials said. It will stay in its burrow at the Sea Cliffs exhibit for “the next 40 days or so,” the aquarium said in a statement. The burrow is similar to the deep burrows that puffins use in the wild.

In its burrow, Macaroni will be fed and cared for by its parents — Vigo and Staypuft — “until it fledges, fully feathered and waterproofed and ready to explore.”

Debra Dial, assistant curator of the Australia and Rain Forest exhibits at the National Aquarium, said the puffins also wear colored bands on their ankles that help staff identify and “recognize each bird.” She said puffins are “sexually monomorphic, meaning males and females look the same.” Experts have to figure out the gender of puffins by testing the DNA in their feathers.

Macaroni’s siblings, Ravioli and Gnocchi, are both females. But experts said they do not yet have the results for Macaroni.



Puffin chick Macaroni being weighed in September. (David Coffey/National Aquarium)

Puffins are not to be confused with penguins.

They are good swimmers, and when grown, they have bright orange legs and webbed feet. They typically stand about a foot tall when adults, and they are best known for “their large, triangular, red-orange bill with a blue-gray base and yellow ridge,” according to experts at the aquarium.

And, unlike penguins, they can fly. Puffins are often dubbed the “parrots of the sea,” according to experts at the aquarium.



The new puffin chick is named Macaroni. (David Coffey/National Aquarium)

In the wild, puffins are found in the Northern Hemisphere, while penguins are in the Southern Hemisphere. Puffins in the Atlantic Ocean are listed as being “vulnerable” by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

This summer, scientists with the National Audubon Society said Atlantic puffins were having a productive season for mating pairs in remote areas off the coast of Maine. The success of the mating was due to many factors, including the abundant availability of the fish they prefer — haddock, hake and herring.

Baby puffins are born with thick coats to keep them warm and usually weigh less than a pound when they hatch. Macaroni weighs almost a pound.
description: A baby puffin was born at the National Aquarium in Baltimore. It's one of 16 born there in the past decade.
